author: By Nikkya Hargrove
title: Making Stories of Struggle a Thing of the Past
description: As a black woman married to a brown woman, it is up to us, the parents of the next generation, to teach new lessons and continue to share our stories with our kids.
content: We come from different worlds, my wife and I, but we both call America home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Bell
title: When a Cemetery Wedding Was Used to End the Spanish Flu
description: Both the dead and the living were on hand for a most unusual exchange of vows at a Jewish burial ground in Queens.
content: Even as New York reopens ever so cautiously, couples hoping to stage big, boisterous weddings in the city still have a good wait ahead of them before they receive a go-ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Elaine Yu
title: Beijing Shuts Down Seafood Market After Dozens Test Positive for Coronavirus
description: Nearly all of the 53 people had worked or shopped at the market, which is said to supply 90 percent of the Chinese capital’s fruit and vegetables.
content: The Beijing authorities shut down a major seafood and produce market and locked down several residential complexes on Saturday after 53 people tested positive for the coronavirus in the city, renewing fears that China’s grip on the pandemic is not yet secure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Split’ and a ‘Dateline’ Special
description: A family of divorce lawyers navigates their own messy relationships, and NBC airs a special report about the coronavirus pandemic.
content: THE SPLIT Stream on Sundance Now, Sundance TV, Amazon, Google Play, Hulu, iTunes and YouTube TV. On the first season of this drama, centered around a family of high-powered divorce lawyers, Ruth Defoe (Deborah Findlay), the matriarch, gives a speech at her daughter’s wedding that gets at the heart of the series. “I have found through life that love and hate are so often intertwined,” she says. “Or perhaps, I should say, that the love that’s there at the start is still there at the end.” As Ruth and her daughters Nina (Annabel Scholey) and Hannah (Nicola Walker), both lawyers, help their clients navigate the often heartless legal world of infidelity, prenuptial agreements and divorce, they are forced to come to terms with the emotional challenges in their own relationships. As Margaret Lyons, a television critic for The New York Times, wrote in her Watching column: “If you like ensemble dramas in which smart, elegant people stand in nice kitchens and sadly ponder their lives, watch this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Carey
title: What We’re Learning About Online Learning
description: As virtual classrooms and online learning proliferate, researchers are working to quantify what works and what doesn’t.
content: Over four days in mid-March, Cindy Hansen, an 11th grade English teacher at Timpanogos High School in Orem, Utah, had to go fully virtual, and took her class of some 30 students reading “The Great Gatsby” online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Art World Wunderkind Arrested Months After Fleeing the U.S.
description: The spectacular rise and fall of Inigo Philbrick, a 33-year-old art dealer whose reported sales in one year exceeded $100 million, ended on a Pacific island.
content: Inigo Philbrick, the elusive contemporary art dealer who disappeared in the fall after being accused of defrauding clients of more than $20 million, was arrested on Thursday by U.S. law enforcement agents on the Pacific island of Vanuatu. Mr. Philbrick has since been transported to Guam, where he is expected to be presented in federal court on June 15, according to a statement from the U.S. attorney’s office of the Southern District of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Savor a Week Full of History and Hope
description: Visit Coney Island from afar, tour the galleries of Art Basel and rock out with Dad to music from “the Adele of the preschool crowd.”
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events  and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Young New Yorkers Want You to Know Why They’re Marching
description: No longer, they say, could they just post on Instagram, or just give money, or just vote. They needed to be out in the streets.
content: They are movement newbies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Strawberry Pie Forever
description: Salmon with miso rice, toasted coconut rice with bok choy and fried eggs, and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Samantha Seneviratne’s fresh strawberry pie (above), Genevieve Ko’s toasted coconut rice with bok choy and fried eggs, and Kay Chun’s roasted salmon with miso rice and ginger-scallion vinaigrette. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Making Arrangements
description: Randolph Ross’s Sunday puzzle scrambles.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This marks Randolph Ross’s 51st Sunday grid for The Times, which obligates him to go to 100, according to the International Cruciverbal Pact that can never be challenged or broken. Fortunately, according to The Times Magazine’s print introduction, Mr. Ross finds himself productive lately. “Staying in my apartment so much these days has increased my crossword solving and constructing,” says he. “I feel fortunate I have an avocation that keeps my brain engaged.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: An Anti-Trump Slam Dunk
description: On the issue of race, America’s Coach boxes out America’s Cretin.
content: WASHINGTON — “Shut up and dribble.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: It’s Trump’s Revolution
description: His supporters wanted a bulwark against liberalism. But his failed presidency is pushing the country to the left.
content: In 1804, the Corsican upstart Napoleon Bonaparte crowned himself as France’s emperor. His mother, born Letizia Ramolino, did not attend the coronation. Informed of her son’s self-elevation, she is said to have remarked coolly: “Let’s hope it lasts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: What the Pandemic Reveals About the Male Ego
description: Why are the rates of coronavirus deaths far lower in many female-led countries?
content: Are female leaders better at fighting a pandemic?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Don’t Leave the W.H.O. Strengthen It.
description: The organization is still the world’s best hope for fighting pandemics.
content: The world is fighting the most serious pandemic in a century, and the United States is in the process of withdrawing from the only international organization equipped to lead that effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: Health Care Advocates Push Back Against Trump’s Erasure of Transgender Rights
description: A new rule narrows the legal definition of sex discrimination in the Affordable Care Act. Major health care providers actively oppose it.
content: Health advocates representing American hospitals, medical groups, insurers and civil rights associations condemned the Trump administration on Saturday for rolling back protections for transgender patients, and for doing so amid a global pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wehner
title: Trump Has Made Alternative Facts a Way of Life
description: The president has taken his degradation of the truth to new lengths, but the basic project has been the same from the start.
content: No president in the history of our Republic has been as disorienting as Donald Trump. His goal, even before he became president, was far more ambitious than to tell mere lies. It was to annihilate the distinction between truth and falsity, to make sure that we no longer share facts in common, to overwhelm people with misinformation and disinformation. It was to induce epistemological vertigo on a mass scale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Mariana Simões
title: Brazil President Embraces Unproven ‘Cure’ as Pandemic Surges
description: President Jair Bolsonaro hailed hydroxychloroquine as a godsend while he railed against quarantine measures and other best practices, undermining the country’s coronavirus response.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — The coronavirus was taking root in Latin America when President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil startled the medical community with a claim: A miracle drug was on hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard A. Oppel Jr
title: Ex-Officer Accused of Murdering Floyd Could Get $50,000 Annual Pension
description: A conviction would not stop Derek Chauvin from receiving his state pension. But George Floyd’s family could potentially seize the funds by winning a lawsuit.
content: Even if the former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin is found guilty of murdering George Floyd, he will qualify to receive what could amount to around $50,000 a year in state pension payments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Johnny Diaz and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Atlanta Police Chief Resigns After Officer Shoots and Kills a Black Man
description: Rayshard Brooks had fallen asleep in his vehicle at a Wendy’s drive-through. He was shot after grabbing a Taser from an officer, the authorities said, prompting fresh unrest in the city.
content: ATLANTA — Less than 24 hours after a white police officer shot and killed an African-American man outside a fast-food restaurant, Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms of Atlanta announced on Saturday that the city’s police chief had resigned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon, Apoorva Mandavilli, Sapna Maheshwari and Jodi Kantor
title: From Cosmetics to NASCAR, Calls for Racial Justice Are Spreading
description: What started as a renewed push for police reform has now touched seemingly every aspect of American life.
content: The reckonings have been swift and dizzying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: Biden’s Vice-Presidential Search: Who’s on the List and Where It Stands
description: The search committee is conducting interviews and seeking private documents, and prospects like Val Demings and Keisha Lance Bottoms are getting a closer look as political currents influence the search.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s advisers have conducted several rounds of interviews with a select group of vice-presidential candidates and are beginning to gather private documents from some of them, as they attempt to winnow a field that features the most diverse set of vice-presidential contenders in history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Special Episode: The Song That Found Me
description: In a time of need, a Times critic is moored by Patti LaBelle — in song, then on the phone.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Club Owners?
description: Trenton Charlson invites us to play some games.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There’s an expression that goes “when you hear hoofbeats, think horses, not zebras.” If you’re doing a Trenton Charlson puzzle, think Quaggas; think lots of high scoring scrabble words, X’s, Q’s and Z’s in unexpected places. Mr. Charlson is more than a one-trick pony and today there are some good puns and factoids to explore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Says He Opposes Police Chokeholds, Except in Certain Situations
description: In a Fox News interview, President Trump was vague in his answer on a key issue in police reform efforts.
content: President Trump appeared to support outlawing chokeholds as a law enforcement practice in an interview with Fox News that aired on Friday, but not before he defended their use in certain situations in a rambling response to a question about police reform efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Split Decisions
description: Fred Piscop makes a splash and a squash.
content: SPLIT DECISIONS — All of the encouragement that I offer to solvers comes from the heart and from my own experience, but I have to admit that the more I solve “Split Decisions” puzzles, the worse I get at them. It’s the necessity of strategizing; I'm either overconfident and run pell-mell through a series of mistakes, or I become paralyzed by the number of possibilities for a series of entries. By definition, this variety of puzzle is full of pitfalls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: Far-Right Groups Stage Counterprotest in London
description: The counterprotests on Saturday turned violent at times, with far-right groups clashing with the police and with people demonstrating against police brutality and racism.
content: The counterprotests on Saturday turned violent at times, with far-right groups clashing with the police and with people demonstrating against police brutality and racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Dowd
title: Stick a Starry Night Sky on Your Ceiling
description: There are about a septillion stars in the observable universe. You can bring a fraction into your home — which is more than enough.
content: By now, you’ve spent more than enough time inside, and although you may be trying to get back out into nature, the options are still limited, especially after sunset. If you have a backyard or balcony and a clear moonless night, you might be able to look up and glimpse a few stars. But with the effects of light pollution, if you want to really see the stars — and lots of them — you’ll need to bring them to you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Johnny Diaz
title: Texas Football Players Call on University to Drop a Song Steeped in Racist History
description: “The Eyes of Texas,” once sung at minstrel shows, plays at football games and other sports events at the University of Texas at Austin.
content: For generations, students at the University of Texas at Austin have stood up at sports games, raised their right hand to form the symbol of the storied Texas Longhorns and belted out “The Eyes of Texas,” a campus anthem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeline Halpert
title: Talking With Relatives Across the Political Divide
description: For those who are engaging in difficult conversations about political differences with family members, here are some ways to keep the dialogue as meaningful as possible.
content: Since the killing of George Floyd, which set off protests three weeks ago, many families have had tough conversations about race — some with relatives expressing dissimilar perspectives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: How to Get Your Kids to Stay 6 Feet Away… From Everything
description: Social distancing is hard — especially for the very young. Here are some ways to get children to care about wearing masks and avoiding germs.
content: It’s hard enough for adults to maintain social distancing — you’ve seen those photos of crowded beaches and parks — but for young children? That’s a whole other challenge. Here are some tips for getting your kids (especially those under 5) to care about wearing masks and steering six feet away from strangers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Dowd
title: Stick a Starry Night Sky on Your Ceiling
description: There are about a septillion stars in the observable universe. You can bring a fraction into your home — which is more than enough.
content: By now, you’ve spent more than enough time inside, and although you may be trying to get back out into nature, the options are still limited, especially after sunset. If you have a backyard or balcony and a clear moonless night, you might be able to look up and glimpse a few stars. But with the effects of light pollution, if you want to really see the stars — and lots of them — you’ll need to bring them to you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Bubba Wallace Thankful for Flag Ban, but NASCAR’s Fans Might Not Be
description: Some NASCAR fans are furious at Wallace because they view the Confederate flag as being part of their Southern heritage, not as a symbol of racism.
content: Now that Darrell Wallace Jr., the sole African-American driver in NASCAR’s top racing series, has persuaded the organization to bar the Confederate flag from its events, he expects his life to be a little different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fernanda Santos
title: What You Can Learn From a Dreamer in Arizona
description: One student’s advice on handling uncertainty and fighting for a better life.
content: PHOENIX — Angel Palazuelos donned a maroon cap and gown one recent afternoon, one of two colors of his alma mater, Metro Tech High School, where almost every student is an immigrant or comes from a family of immigrants. The school is part of the Phoenix Union High School District, one of the largest in the country and one whose enrollment reflects Arizona’s impending demographic destiny as a majority Latino state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: Tanker Truck Blast on China Highway Kills 19
description: The explosion of the tanker, which carried liquefied gas, engulfed nearby vehicles and buildings, leaving people trapped.
content: Nineteen people died and more than 170 were injured in the eastern Chinese province of Zhejiang on Saturday after a truck carrying liquefied gas exploded on a highway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Mike Baker
title: Rage and Promises Followed Ferguson, but Little Changed
description: Millions of dollars were spent to alter overly aggressive policing after the killing of Michael Brown in 2014, with little result. Will George Floyd’s death be different?
content: America has been here before: a black man on the asphalt dying at the hands of the police. Convulsive protests across the country. A national reckoning. Vows to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: The Economy Is Reeling. The Tech Giants Spy Opportunity.
description: Many companies are retreating. But Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google and Microsoft are placing bets to get even bigger.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Even as Facebook grappled this month with an internal revolt and a cascade of criticism over its refusal to take action on President Trump’s inflammatory posts, the social network was actively making other bets behind the scenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Sergey Ponomarev
title: Too Close for Comfort, and the Virus, in Russia’s Communal Apartments
description: Riding out a virus lockdown in an apartment shared with 20 or so other people is about as unpleasant as it would seem. Along with the virus, “a silent paranoia” spreads.
content: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Through the thin wall separating her from her neighbors, Dr. Anzhela Kirilova began to hear the rasping cough associated with Covid-19 sometime in May. That was hardly a surprise, as a few weeks earlier her neighbors had heard the same cough coming from her room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Tommie Smith’s Fist Is Still Raised: ‘We Still Need to Fight’
description: Smith, whose iconic protest alongside John Carlos at the 1968 Olympics shined a light on racial inequality, talked about today’s protests, Colin Kaepernick and what needs to happen now.
content: In 1968, Tommie Smith and John Carlos stepped to the podium at the Olympics in Mexico City to receive their medals in the 200-meter dash. Wearing black socks and no shoes to represent poverty and black gloves to signify black power and liberation, the sprinters raised their fists.
source.name: The New York Times

title: China Reports 57 New Coronavirus Cases Amid Beijing Outbreak
description: Officials closed a market that handles 90 percent of the capital’s fresh fruit and vegetables after dozens of people tested positive. It was China’s highest number of new infections in two months.
content: China on Sunday reported 57 new confirmed infections, its highest single-day tally in two months, renewing fears that the country’s grip on the pandemic is not yet secure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Jenny Gross
title: A Black Man Was Found Hanging From a Tree, and a Community Demands Answers
description: Robert Fuller’s sister said on Saturday that the initial determination by officials that her brother died by suicide did not make sense.
content: City officials in Palmdale, Calif., said on Saturday that they support calls by activists and residents who have demanded an independent investigation into the death of a 24-year-old black man who was found hanging from a tree in a public square this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker
title: Fox News Removes a Digitally Altered Image of Seattle Protests
description: Fox News acknowledged that one photo was a combination of several images, and a second was taken in a different city.
content: Fox News removed photos accompanying its coverage of Seattle’s demonstrations from its website on Friday after acknowledging that one was a combination of several different images and a second photo was of a fiery scene in a different city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 13, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 13, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about the renewed scrutiny of European police that has followed the demonstrations against police brutality in the United States misstated the given name of the Human Rights Watch director in France. She is Bénédicte Jeannerod, not Béatrice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda McCracken
title: Finally, a Wedding. It Was About Time.
description: The author learned that loving is just as much about holding on as it is letting go.
content: When I was 6, I had an imaginary husband I named Dave the Watchmaker. We had a wedding ceremony in the living room where my grandma sat as the lone guest while my mother played the organ. I carried a giant baby doll with me down the aisle to meet Dave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Ewing
title: How a New Yorker Cartoonist Spends Her Sundays
description: Working from home, Liana Finck seems to get plenty of inspiration watching people from her apartment window.
content: Liana Finck’s cartoons have wobbly lines, potato-headed characters with names like “blunt person,” and a deeply sympathetic contemporary anguish. “The most relatable thing,” Ms. Finck said, “is to show the thought in its original, messy form.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Prime Minister Boris Johnson Stirs Culture War Over Churchill Statue
description: After “racist” was scrawled on a Churchill statue during protests over the killing of George Floyd, Mr. Johnson has spoken up for his political idol.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Friday stirred a fraught debate over symbols of his country’s past, accusing protesters of seeking to “censor our past” and telling them it was “absurd and shameful” that a statue of Winston Churchill needed to be covered to protect it from being vandalized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Teachings of the Philosopher of the Black Forest
description: Christian Streich, the coach of unassuming Freiburg, acts as German soccer’s unofficial social conscience. The Bundesliga’s recent stoppage gave him a chance to reflect on his relationship with his sport.
content: Christian Streich has to go. He is conscious that it is nearing 10 a.m., and training is about to start. His S.C. Freiburg players — he calls them his “colleagues” — will soon be out on the field, wondering where their coach has gone. With a hint of apology, he wonders if we might, perhaps, make these the last couple of questions?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Kenny
title: 8 Are Shot in San Antonio by Man Claiming to Be U.F.C. Fighter
description: The man, who said he was part of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, had been turned away from a bar, the police said. None of the victims’ injuries were said to be life-threatening.
content: Eight people were shot late Friday in a San Antonio parking lot by a man who, after being turned away from a bar, came back and opened fire with a rifle, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: 5 Podcasts at the Intersection of Pride Month and the Black Lives Matter Movement
description: This June has restored the spirit of protest to Pride celebrations. Here are shows to help you understand the moment.
content: This year, Pride has been forced back to its roots. Instead of celebrities waving from floats sponsored by TD Bank and Absolut Vodka, pandemic-masked protesters are marching in the streets demanding justice for black lives. Rainbow flags have been replaced with signs with the names of those killed by the police, like Tony McDade, a black trans man in Tallahassee, Fla. These protests may be perhaps the most genuine honoring of Pride, an annual commemoration of the 1969 Stonewall uprising, in which black and brown L.G.B.T.Q. people were a driving force. There is much to learn this Pride, and a legion of queer voices in podcasting can help you gain insight, find representation and feel comfort during this time. Here are a few of our recommendations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Is It OK to Have Your Air-Conditioners Installed Yet?
description: It’s getting hot out there, but a lot of New Yorkers are still nervous about bringing workers into their apartments.
content: Q: I haven’t hired anyone to install my window unit air-conditioners yet because I’ve been concerned about letting workers into my apartment during the pandemic. But now that the city is reopening, does that mean it’s safe to install them? Will my Manhattan co-op even allow someone to come in and do the work?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
title: In Every Corner of Bangkok, Spirits Need a Home and Maybe a Strawberry Fanta
description: Across Thailand’s crowded capital, there are spirits who must be placated with a comfy place to live. The coronavirus is no excuse to cut back on the coddling.
content: BANGKOK — These spirits were not wearing face masks. They appeared well fed, untroubled by the hunger pangs that have afflicted some Thais during the lean times of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: So You Want to Learn About Juneteenth?
description: On June 19, 1865, enslaved African-Americans in Galveston, Texas, were told they were free. Now, 155 years later, people in cities and towns across the U.S. continue to mark the occasion with celebrations.
content: Juneteenth, an annual holiday commemorating the end of slavery in the United States, has been celebrated by African-Americans since the late 1800s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
title: In Every Corner of Bangkok, Spirits Need a Home and Maybe a Strawberry Fanta
description: Across Thailand’s crowded capital, there are spirits who must be placated with a comfy place to live. The coronavirus is no excuse to cut back on the coddling.
content: BANGKOK — These spirits were not wearing face masks. They appeared well fed, untroubled by the hunger pangs that have afflicted some Thais during the lean times of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Moves Tulsa Rally Date ‘Out of Respect’ for Juneteenth
description: The campaign rally, his first since the lockdowns forced by the coronavirus pandemic, had been scheduled for June 19, or Juneteenth, which marks the end of slavery. The president announced he would delay it by a day.
content: President Trump bowed to pressure on Friday night and announced that he would delay his upcoming campaign rally in Tulsa, Okla., rather than hold it on the day that honors the end of slavery in the United States and is considered a major holiday by many African-Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Faced With Crisis and Re-election, Senate Republicans Blame China
description: Politically endangered Republicans are scrambling to make their contests referendums on China rather than the coronavirus pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — When Senator Martha McSally, one of the most politically endangered Republicans, was asked last month about reports that President Trump had brushed away warnings from his own aides about the looming threat of the coronavirus, she promptly pivoted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Cory Booker on Newark Pride, Black Lives Matter and ‘This Distraught Present’
description: The senator discussed police mistreatment of black Americans in a Q. and A. with The Times. “You can’t be comfortable with this,” he said. “And it’s our comfort with it that has allowed it to fester.”
content: Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey has long made criminal justice core to his politics, a focus that began during his days at Stanford, continued through his two terms as mayor of Newark and eventually formed the backbone of his presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laylah Amatullah Barrayn
title: ‘It’s Something I Wanted to Carry With Me’: Marking a Movement in Ink
description: After the death of George Floyd and the protests that followed, three women speak about why they wanted to memorialize this moment by getting tattoos.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — After George Floyd died in police custody in Minneapolis last month, Dashinque Hall watched her city become the center of a protest movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Latest Crop of West Point Graduates Includes First Observant Sikh Cadet
description: Anmol Narang said she was inspired to apply to West Point after visiting the Pearl Harbor National Memorial in Hawaii.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Trump took the stage on Saturday to deliver the commencement speech at West Point, one of the new Army officers he addressed was an Indian-American woman breaking a barrier as old as the 218-year-old military academy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clive D. L. Wynne
title: Call Off the Dogs, Mr. Trump
description: They are creatures with a knack for loving humans, not tools of oppression.
content: When President Trump tweeted late last month that the Secret Service was prepared to sic “the most vicious dogs” on protesters outside the White House, I was dismayed, as both a dog lover and an American citizen. I strongly suspect that the handlers of the highly trained dogs that assist the agents in their duties were deeply shocked, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: G.O.P. Congressman Faces Primary After Officiating Same-Sex Wedding
description: Representative Denver Riggleman could lose his bid for re-election in an unusual drive-through primary held at a Virginia church on Saturday.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Denver Riggleman, a freshman Republican from Virginia, is facing a primary challenge that will be decided on Saturday in a drive-through state convention following an uproar among local activists after Mr. Riggleman officiated a same-sex wedding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A St. John’s Fencing Coach Is Fired After Making Racist Remarks
description: Boris Vaksman was recorded in a private lesson saying black people “steal” and “kill,” adding that he believed Abraham Lincoln “made a mistake.”
content: An assistant fencing coach for St. John’s University was fired this week after making derogatory remarks about black people in a private lesson, including that they cause “the most trouble.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch, Weiyi Cai, Gabriel Gianordoli, Morrigan McCarthy and Jugal K. Patel
title: How Black Lives Matter Reached Every Corner of America
description: George Floyd’s death has sparked more than two weeks of protests in all 50 states. See how the movement spread.
content: George Floyd’s death has sparked more than two weeks of protests in all 50 states. See how the movement spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Zach Montague
title: Trump Speaks at West Point Graduation Amid Tensions With Military Leaders
description: The president said nothing about his clash with the Pentagon over sending active-duty troops to put down demonstrations protesting the death of George Floyd.
content: President Trump told the Army’s newest officers on Saturday that they will not have to serve in “endless wars” being waged in “far away lands,” but made no mention of his thwarted effort in recent days to deploy the active-duty military to the streets of American cities over the objections of Pentagon leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump Made Inaccurate Claims About the Military During His West Point Speech
description: The president made misleading claims about his military budgets, the fight against the Islamic State and wars in the Middle East.
content: President Trump oversold his administration’s military record in a commencement speech at the United States Military Academy at West Point on Saturday. Here’s a fact-check of his claims.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Houses of Prayer, Hope and Testing for Most Affected
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 13, 2020.
content: “I know I’m not superwoman. I’m not going to do reckless things and risk reinfecting myself or reinfecting my parents.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louis Lucero II
title: Celebrate Pride With Town Halls and Club Beats
description: A variety of events have gone digital this year — and they’re joined by the marquee Global Pride livestream.
content: If you’re feeling conflicted about how to celebrate Pride this year, you’re hardly alone. Three months after the coronavirus pandemic turned the world on its head, America has been rocked by coast-to-coast protests inspired by George Floyd, whose death has led millions to cry out for an end to police brutality — and an end to police departments generally.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Risks When Colleges Reopen
description: In response to Op-Eds by college presidents and professors, readers analyze whether proposed measures to open safely are likely to work.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: Get Creative to Celebrate Dad
description: During the coronavirus outbreak, the best Father’s Day gifts should be personal and priceless, in every sense of the word.
content: Celebrating Father’s Day is shaping up to be tricky. The country is reopening, but experts have said to remain cautious and limit indoor gatherings. And, with millions of Americans out of a job, this may not be the best time to splurge on a present. What to do instead? Below, some meaningful ways you can honor Dad this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: Vet Your Social Media
description: Before hitting like or retweet on a post about the protests, it’s important to know that the accounts you are following are trustworthy.
content: With the combination of camera phones and social media, more people than ever are being made aware of incidents of police brutality and racial inequality, and of the protests they have touched off.But making sense of the deluge of posts in the present moment can be difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Harry Glickman, Who Brought Basketball to Oregon, Dies at 96
description: A native of Portland, Mr. Glickman founded the Trail Blazers and helped shape them into one of the N.B.A.’s great success stories.
content: Harry Glickman, who founded the Portland Trail Blazers of the National Basketball Association and was widely considered the father of professional sports in Oregon, died on Wednesday in Portland. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: Police Reform Is Necessary. But How Do We Do It?
description: A discussion about changes in policing, moderated by Emily Bazelon.
content: A discussion about changes in policing, moderated by Emily Bazelon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Roger Cohen: The Outcry Over ‘Both Sides’ Journalism
description: Moral clarity or only one acceptable truth?
content: The acting editorial page editor, Kathleen Kingsbury, wrote about the decision to publish our writers’ responses to the Tom Cotton Op-Ed in Friday’s edition of our Opinion Today newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: A Reckoning at Condé Nast
description: “It’s hard to be a person of color at this company,” a staff member said. In response to an uprising, Anna Wintour and the chief executive, Roger Lynch, offered apologies.
content: This was supposed to be Condé Nast’s year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: U.N. Expresses Horror at Mass Graves in Libya
description: The discovery of eight mass graves near Tripoli was a grim reminder of the atrocities that have punctuated the country’s conflict.
content: CAIRO — The United Nations chief expressed horror at the discovery of at least eight mass graves in Libya in recent days and called for a prompt and transparent investigation into possible war crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jia Lynn Yang
title: The Surprising Origin of Our Modern Nation of Immigrants
description: The landmark 1965 immigration law prioritized family ties, but originally as a way to keep America white.
content: It was early evening when Michael Feighan arrived at the White House on May 7, 1965. A tall, dour Democratic congressman from Ohio, Feighan had an important meeting with President Lyndon B. Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keeanga-Yamahtta Taylor
title: The End of Black Politics
description: Our best leaders are organizers and workers — not elected officials.
content: Young black people have exploded in rebellion over the grotesque killing of George Floyd. We are now witnessing the broadest protest movement in American history. And yet the response of black elected officials has been cautious and uninspired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Magra, Elian Peltier and Constant Méheut
title: Far-Right Groups Push Back as Protesters Rally in Europe
description: After a week of demonstrations against racism in Europe, far-right counterdemonstrators turned out on Saturday and attacked the police in London. Prime Minister Boris Johnson denounced the “racist thuggery.”
content: LONDON — Thousands of people rallied against police brutality and racism in European cities on Saturday, punctuating a week of protests across the continent, but far-right demonstrators also emerged in large groups for the first time — particularly in London — leading to sometimes violent confrontations that included attacks on police officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Remains in Idaho Identified as Those of Missing Children
description: Chad Daybell, who is married to the children’s mother, was arrested on Tuesday after investigators found human remains on his property.
content: Human remains discovered on an Idaho man’s property were identified as belonging to his wife’s two children who had been missing for months, the police said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Family of Atlanta Shooting Victim Disputes Police Account
description: The officer who shot and killed Rayshard Brooks has been fired, the Atlanta police said. The city’s police chief has resigned as well.
content: Atlanta’s police chief resigned on Saturday, less than 24 hours after a white police officer shot and killed an African-American man at a Wendy’s drive-through who had run from the police after failing a sobriety check and taking an officer’s Taser, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Guaranteed Ingredient in Any Coronavirus Vaccine? Thousands of Volunteers
description: Two sisters in Missouri were among the first to have an unproven coronavirus vaccine injected in their bodies. If it makes it to market, it would also be the first DNA vaccine for any disease.
content: Not long after researchers completed their work with mice, guinea pigs, ferrets and monkeys, Human Subject 8, an art director for a software company in Missouri, received an injection. Four days later, her sister, a schoolteacher, became Subject 14.
source.name: The New York Times
